issue.title: sitePackages variable is not the one you expect at runtime
issue.body:
The global constant `sitePackages` is determined from the host at compile time, and will not report the correct site packages if you run plz from within a virtualenv. The value should be coming from runtime and should be determined from an heuristic.

```nim
  sitePackages = staticExec"""python3 -c "print(__import__('site').getsitepackages()[0])" """ ## https://stackoverflow.com/questions/122327/how-do-i-find-the-location-of-my-python-site-packages-directory#12950101
```

issue.title: capacity for seq and string
issue.body:
## Abstract

Allow read-only access to `cap` of `seq` and `string`.
The name is suggested to be `capacity` instead of `cap`.
It is a very simple and tiny RFC.


## Motivation

It is a nice information to design macros and metaprogramming, 
like unrollings, `setLen`, `newStringOfCap`, `newSeqOfCap`, etc.

`len` and `setLen` of `seq` and `string` is usable, but `cap` is not.

## Examples

I imagine something kinda like 

```
func capacity*(self: string): int
```

(Pseudocode-ish)

Change would require 3 ~ 5 lines at most (?).

### Before

`cap` is not accessible, it is always unknown.

This can not be implemented with third-party Nimble modules, in a non-hacky way at least.

### After

`myString.capacity` returns an `int` with the allocated capacity.

## Backward incompatibility

No backward-incompatible changes, because it is a new proc.

issue.title: sitePackages variable is not the one you expect at runtime
issue.body:
The global constant `sitePackages` is determined from the host at compile time, and will not report the correct site packages if you run plz from within a virtualenv. The value should be coming from runtime and should be determined from an heuristic.

```nim
  sitePackages = staticExec"""python3 -c "print(__import__('site').getsitepackages()[0])" """ ## https://stackoverflow.com/questions/122327/how-do-i-find-the-location-of-my-python-site-packages-directory#12950101
```

issue.title: Install doesn't properly install
issue.body:
Love the idea ! Great work !

I've tried running install and i just get eggs in site-packages, not the unpacked python modules and .dist-info folder.

This also makes it impossible to uninstall (no .dist-info in site-packages if installed via plz, but it is if installed via pip). 
It also assumes that package names are case insensitive (for example if i do `plz uninstall flask` it doesn't find it because it was installed in `Flask.*.dist-info`):
```
  for a in args: # RECORD Metadata file (CSV without file extension).
    for item in walkFiles(sitePackages / a & "*.dist-info" / "RECORD"):
      recordFiles.add item
```

issue.title: Install doesn't properly install
issue.body:
Love the idea ! Great work !

I've tried running install and i just get eggs in site-packages, not the unpacked python modules and .dist-info folder.

This also makes it impossible to uninstall (no .dist-info in site-packages if installed via plz, but it is if installed via pip). 
It also assumes that package names are case insensitive (for example if i do `plz uninstall flask` it doesn't find it because it was installed in `Flask.*.dist-info`):

  for a in args: # RECORD Metadata file (CSV without file extension).

issue.title: Automatically import std/assertions in runnableExamples
issue.body:
### Abstract

Automatically import std/assertions in runnableExamples blocks.

### Motivation

Pretty much every runnableExamples block has an `assert` statement. Would save hundreds of lines of code to not have to explicitly import it in every single one.

### Description

Seems pretty self explanatory. Don't know about implementation details.

### Code Examples

```nim
runnableExamples:
  assert true # works
```

### Backwards Compatibility

_No response_

comment.body: Workaround `runnableExamples"--import:std/assertions":`.

issue.title: Don't allow vars of the same name to be declared in nested blocks
issue.body:
### Description

Here's a sample test case:

```nim
proc myTest(input: string) =

  var str = "abc"

  if input == "def":
    var str = "def"  ## BUG, doesn't assign to the outer var str

  echo str


# Main
myTest("def")
```

### Nim Version

1.6.10

### Current Output

```text
Output: abc
```


### Expected Output

```text
The compiler should raise an error for the 2nd declaration of str in the nested block.
```


### Possible Solution

A change to the Nim compiler to raise an error for this case.

### Additional Information

By not raising an error, subtle bugs can be introduced into the source that are difficult to track down.

comment.body:
If you change it likely a lot of code may break,
because some stuff may be triggered by going out of scope like Destructors,
also because function arguments are immutable by default its a common practice to do:

```nim
proc f(a: int) =
  var a = a
  inc a
```

pull_request.title: stdlib organization & documentation improvements
pull_request.body:
`asyncmacro` is converted to an import/export in `asyncdispatch` instead of an include, since `async` imports `asyncmacro` as well. This seems to work without extra changes?

`jshttpcore` is added to combine `jsformdata` and `jsheaders`. In an ideal world these were combined from the start, now it would be really annoying to get rid of the single module versions.

The following modules are added to `doc/lib.md` (note that some of these have messages like "unstable API" or "experimental", but these messages have been there for years, and some modules already in `doc/lib.md` have them as well):
* compilesettings, effecttraits (core)
* formatfloat\*, objectdollar\*, widestrs\* (strings)
* reservedmem, exitprocs\*, syncio\*, appdirs\*\*, dirs\*\*, envvars\*\*, files\*\*, oserrors\*\*, paths\*\*, symlinks\*\* (generic OS services)
* async, asyncmacro, socketstreams (internet protocols)
* isolation, tasks, typedthreads* (threading)
* genasts (generators)
* decls, importutils, wrapnils, assertions\* (miscellaneous)
* jsfetch, jshttpcore, jsre (javascript)
\* part of `nimPreviewSlimSystem`
\*\* part of `os` module splitup

The following modules have changed sections:
* lenientops (core -> math)
* ropes, strtabs (strings -> collections)
* parseutils, pegs (strings -> parsers)
* marshal (generic OS services -> serialization (new section))
* jsonutils (parsers -> serialization (new section))

The following deprecated modules have been removed from documentation and moved to  `lib/deprecated/pure`:
* sums (moved to nimble package)
* mersenne (graveyard)
* oswalkdir

The following modules have not been included in `doc/lib.md` for various reasons:
* jsformdata, jsheaders (redundant with jshttpcore)
* pathnorm (seems dubious)
* chains (too small/seems internal)
* experimental/diff (seems internal)
* rtarrays (says "not ready for other people to use")
* outparams (tied to experimental feature and seems temporary)
* prelude (non-essential, tiny module that has to be `include`d to use)
* ssl_certs/ssl_config (are these useful for other people?)
* streamwrapper (straight up don't understand this module, it's internally used by `osproc`)
* sysatomics (deprecated in place of std/atomics which is included)

If you have any objections, please say so.

commits.message:
Handle ppc CPU architecture (#20920)

* Remove confusing "ppc" block

The PowerPC arch is called "powerpc" in platforms.nim

The makefile shipped in release 1.6.10 populates the oFiles variable when myos=linux and mycpu=powerpc
mycpu=ppc instead leads to  ``no C code generated for: [linux: ppc].  Stop``

* Handle ucpu=ppc
Merge branch 'devel' into jsformdata0

issue.title: dom: remove X* = ref XObj [backport]
issue.body: The `XObj` variants are private and not used anywhere in `dom`, so the docs of the fields for these types are hidden (hence the backport). Value type objects don't make sense for opaque JS types anyway, there is nothing wrong with just using `ref object` directly.

comment.body: I think those should be `ref object of JsRoot`.

issue.title: sitePackages variable is not the one you expect at runtime
issue.body:
The global constant `sitePackages` is determined from the host at compile time, and will not report the correct site packages if you run plz from within a virtualenv. The value should be coming from runtime and should be determined from an heuristic.

```nim
  sitePackages = staticExec"""python3 -c "print(__import__('site').getsitepackages()[0])" """ ## https://stackoverflow.com/questions/122327/how-do-i-find-the-location-of-my-python-site-packages-directory#12950101
```

issue.title: capacity for seq and string
issue.body:
## Abstract

Allow read-only access to `cap` of `seq` and `string`.
The name is suggested to be `capacity` instead of `cap`.
It is a very simple and tiny RFC.


## Motivation

It is a nice information to design macros and metaprogramming, 
like unrollings, `setLen`, `newStringOfCap`, `newSeqOfCap`, etc.

`len` and `setLen` of `seq` and `string` is usable, but `cap` is not.

## Examples

I imagine something kinda like 

```
func capacity*(self: string): int
```

(Pseudocode-ish)

Change would require 3 ~ 5 lines at most (?).

### Before

`cap` is not accessible, it is always unknown.

This can not be implemented with third-party Nimble modules, in a non-hacky way at least.

### After

`myString.capacity` returns an `int` with the allocated capacity.

## Backward incompatibility

No backward-incompatible changes, because it is a new proc.

issue.body:
The global constant `sitePackages` is determined from the host at compile time, and will not report the correct site packages if you run plz from within a virtualenv. The value should be coming from runtime and should be determined from an heuristic.

```

issue.title: Install doesn't properly install
issue.body:
Love the idea ! Great work !

I've tried running install and i just get eggs in site-packages, not the unpacked python modules and .dist-info folder.

This also makes it impossible to uninstall (no .dist-info in site-packages if installed via plz, but it is if installed via pip). 
It also assumes that package names are case insensitive (for example if i do `plz uninstall flask` it doesn't find it because it was installed in `Flask.*.dist-info`):
```
  for a in args: # RECORD Metadata file (CSV without file extension).
    for item in walkFiles(sitePackages / a & "*.dist-info" / "RECORD"):
      recordFiles.add item
```

issue.title: Automatically import std/assertions in runnableExamples
issue.body:
### Abstract

Automatically import std/assertions in runnableExamples blocks.

### Motivation

Pretty much every runnableExamples block has an `assert` statement. Would save hundreds of lines of code to not have to explicitly import it in every single one.

### Description

Seems pretty self explanatory. Don't know about implementation details.

### Code Examples

```nim
runnableExamples:
  assert true # works
```

### Backwards Compatibility

_No response_

comment.body: Workaround `runnableExamples"--import:std/assertions":`.

issue.title: Don't allow vars of the same name to be declared in nested blocks
issue.body:
### Description

Here's a sample test case:

```nim
proc myTest(input: string) =

  var str = "abc"

  if input == "def":
    var str = "def"  ## BUG, doesn't assign to the outer var str

  echo str


# Main
myTest("def")
```

### Nim Version

1.6.10

### Current Output

```text
Output: abc
```


### Expected Output

```text
The compiler should raise an error for the 2nd declaration of str in the nested block.
```


### Possible Solution

A change to the Nim compiler to raise an error for this case.

### Additional Information

By not raising an error, subtle bugs can be introduced into the source that are difficult to track down.

comment.body:
If you change it likely a lot of code may break,
because some stuff may be triggered by going out of scope like Destructors,
also because function arguments are immutable by default its a common practice to do:

```nim
proc f(a: int) =
  var a = a
  inc a
```

pull_request.title: stdlib organization & documentation improvements
pull_request.body:
`asyncmacro` is converted to an import/export in `asyncdispatch` instead of an include, since `async` imports `asyncmacro` as well. This seems to work without extra changes?

`jshttpcore` is added to combine `jsformdata` and `jsheaders`. In an ideal world these were combined from the start, now it would be really annoying to get rid of the single module versions.

The following modules are added to `doc/lib.md` (note that some of these have messages like "unstable API" or "experimental", but these messages have been there for years, and some modules already in `doc/lib.md` have them as well):
* compilesettings, effecttraits (core)
* formatfloat\*, objectdollar\*, widestrs\* (strings)
* reservedmem, exitprocs\*, syncio\*, appdirs\*\*, dirs\*\*, envvars\*\*, files\*\*, oserrors\*\*, paths\*\*, symlinks\*\* (generic OS services)
* async, asyncmacro, socketstreams (internet protocols)
* isolation, tasks, typedthreads* (threading)
* genasts (generators)
* decls, importutils, wrapnils, assertions\* (miscellaneous)
* jsfetch, jshttpcore, jsre (javascript)
\* part of `nimPreviewSlimSystem`
\*\* part of `os` module splitup

The following modules have changed sections:
* lenientops (core -> math)
* ropes, strtabs (strings -> collections)
* parseutils, pegs (strings -> parsers)
* marshal (generic OS services -> serialization (new section))
* jsonutils (parsers -> serialization (new section))

The following deprecated modules have been removed from documentation and moved to  `lib/deprecated/pure`:
* sums (moved to nimble package)
* mersenne (graveyard)
* oswalkdir

The following modules have not been included in `doc/lib.md` for various reasons:
* jsformdata, jsheaders (redundant with jshttpcore)
* pathnorm (seems dubious)
* chains (too small/seems internal)
* experimental/diff (seems internal)
* rtarrays (says "not ready for other people to use")
* outparams (tied to experimental feature and seems temporary)
* prelude (non-essential, tiny module that has to be `include`d to use)
* ssl_certs/ssl_config (are these useful for other people?)
* streamwrapper (straight up don't understand this module, it's internally used by `osproc`)
* sysatomics (deprecated in place of std/atomics which is included)

If you have any objections, please say so.

commits.message:
Handle ppc CPU architecture (#20920)

* Remove confusing "ppc" block

The PowerPC arch is called "powerpc" in platforms.nim

The makefile shipped in release 1.6.10 populates the oFiles variable when myos=linux and mycpu=powerpc
mycpu=ppc instead leads to  ``no C code generated for: [linux: ppc].  Stop``

* Handle ucpu=ppc

issue.title: sitePackages variable is not the one you expect at runtime
issue.body:
The global constant `sitePackages` is determined from the host at compile time, and will not report the correct site packages if you run plz from within a virtualenv. The value should be coming from runtime and should be determined from an heuristic.

```nim
  sitePackages = staticExec"""python3 -c "print(__import__('site').getsitepackages()[0])" """ ## https://stackoverflow.com/questions/122327/how-do-i-find-the-location-of-my-python-site-packages-directory#12950101
```

issue.title: capacity for seq and string
issue.body:
## Abstract

Allow read-only access to `cap` of `seq` and `string`.
The name is suggested to be `capacity` instead of `cap`.
It is a very simple and tiny RFC.


## Motivation

It is a nice information to design macros and metaprogramming, 
like unrollings, `setLen`, `newStringOfCap`, `newSeqOfCap`, etc.

`len` and `setLen` of `seq` and `string` is usable, but `cap` is not.

## Examples

I imagine something kinda like 

```
func capacity*(self: string): int
```

(Pseudocode-ish)

Change would require 3 ~ 5 lines at most (?).

### Before

`cap` is not accessible, it is always unknown.

This can not be implemented with third-party Nimble modules, in a non-hacky way at least.

### After

`myString.capacity` returns an `int` with the allocated capacity.

## Backward incompatibility

No backward-incompatible changes, because it is a new proc.

issue.title: Install doesn't properly install
issue.body:
Love the idea ! Great work !

I've tried running install and i just get eggs in site-packages, not the unpacked python modules and .dist-info folder.

This also makes it impossible to uninstall (no .dist-info in site-packages if installed via plz, but it is if installed via pip). 
It also assumes that package names are case insensitive (for example if i do `plz uninstall flask` it doesn't find it because it was installed in `Flask.*.dist-info`):
```
  for a in args: # RECORD Metadata file (CSV without file extension).
    for item in walkFiles(sitePackages / a & "*.dist-info" / "RECORD"):
      recordFiles.add item
```

issue.title: Automatically import std/assertions in runnableExamples
issue.body:
### Abstract

Automatically import std/assertions in runnableExamples blocks.

### Motivation

Pretty much every runnableExamples block has an `assert` statement. Would save hundreds of lines of code to not have to explicitly import it in every single one.

### Description

Seems pretty self explanatory. Don't know about implementation details.

### Code Examples

```nim
runnableExamples:
  assert true # works
```

### Backwards Compatibility

_No response_

comment.body: Workaround `runnableExamples"--import:std/assertions":`.

issue.title: Don't allow vars of the same name to be declared in nested blocks
issue.body:
### Description

Here's a sample test case:

```nim
proc myTest(input: string) =

  var str = "abc"

  if input == "def":
    var str = "def"  ## BUG, doesn't assign to the outer var str

  echo str


# Main
myTest("def")
```

### Nim Version

1.6.10

### Current Output

```text
Output: abc
```


### Expected Output

```text
The compiler should raise an error for the 2nd declaration of str in the nested block.
```


### Possible Solution

A change to the Nim compiler to raise an error for this case.

### Additional Information

By not raising an error, subtle bugs can be introduced into the source that are difficult to track down.

comment.body:
If you change it likely a lot of code may break,
because some stuff may be triggered by going out of scope like Destructors,
also because function arguments are immutable by default its a common practice to do:

```nim
proc f(a: int) =
  var a = a
  inc a
```

pull_request.title: stdlib organization & documentation improvements
pull_request.body:
`asyncmacro` is converted to an import/export in `asyncdispatch` instead of an include, since `async` imports `asyncmacro` as well. This seems to work without extra changes?

`jshttpcore` is added to combine `jsformdata` and `jsheaders`. In an ideal world these were combined from the start, now it would be really annoying to get rid of the single module versions.

The following modules are added to `doc/lib.md` (note that some of these have messages like "unstable API" or "experimental", but these messages have been there for years, and some modules already in `doc/lib.md` have them as well):
* compilesettings, effecttraits (core)
* formatfloat\*, objectdollar\*, widestrs\* (strings)
* reservedmem, exitprocs\*, syncio\*, appdirs\*\*, dirs\*\*, envvars\*\*, files\*\*, oserrors\*\*, paths\*\*, symlinks\*\* (generic OS services)
* async, asyncmacro, socketstreams (internet protocols)
* isolation, tasks, typedthreads* (threading)
* genasts (generators)
* decls, importutils, wrapnils, assertions\* (miscellaneous)
* jsfetch, jshttpcore, jsre (javascript)
\* part of `nimPreviewSlimSystem`
\*\* part of `os` module splitup

The following modules have changed sections:
* lenientops (core -> math)
* ropes, strtabs (strings -> collections)
* parseutils, pegs (strings -> parsers)
* marshal (generic OS services -> serialization (new section))
* jsonutils (parsers -> serialization (new section))

The following deprecated modules have been removed from documentation and moved to  `lib/deprecated/pure`:
* sums (moved to nimble package)
* mersenne (graveyard)
* oswalkdir

The following modules have not been included in `doc/lib.md` for various reasons:
* jsformdata, jsheaders (redundant with jshttpcore)
* pathnorm (seems dubious)
* chains (too small/seems internal)
* experimental/diff (seems internal)
* rtarrays (says "not ready for other people to use")
* outparams (tied to experimental feature and seems temporary)
* prelude (non-essential, tiny module that has to be `include`d to use)
* ssl_certs/ssl_config (are these useful for other people?)
* streamwrapper (straight up don't understand this module, it's internally used by `osproc`)
* sysatomics (deprecated in place of std/atomics which is included)

If you have any objections, please say so.

commits.message:
Handle ppc CPU architecture (#20920)

* Remove confusing "ppc" block

The PowerPC arch is called "powerpc" in platforms.nim

The makefile shipped in release 1.6.10 populates the oFiles variable when myos=linux and mycpu=powerpc
mycpu=ppc instead leads to  ``no C code generated for: [linux: ppc].  Stop``

* Handle ucpu=ppc
Merge branch 'devel' into jsformdata0
